dataset.description: Block groups from the 2010 Census.
dataset.title: Census 2010 Block Groups

dataset.title: Census 2010 Tracts

dataset.description: City of Evanston Public Works picks up recycling on a four day cycle.
dataset.title: Recycling collection days

dataset.description: Traffic circles are a traffic calming device employed by the City of Evanston along with speed humps.
dataset.title: Traffic circles

dataset.description: Annexations by the City of Evanston through the years.
dataset.title: Annexation Chronology

dataset.description: City of Evanston tax parcels with PIN, landuse, and a link to the Cook County Property Tax Portal.
dataset.title: City Property

dataset.description: This layer shows driveway edges within the City of Evanston.
dataset.title: Driveways

dataset.description: Each year, the City of Evanston receives approximately $2 million in federal Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) funds as an entitlement community of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). For more information see the City of Evanston's web page on the CDBG program.
dataset.title: CDBG Target Area

dataset.description: Road and rail bridges in the City of Evanston.
dataset.title: Bridges

dataset.description: The City of Evanston is divided into nine wards. One alderman is elected to represent each ward.
dataset.title: Wards

dataset.description: The City of Evanston's local historic districts consist of the Northeast, Ridge, and Lakeshore historic districts.
dataset.title: Local historic districts

dataset.description: Bridges over roadways in the City of Evanston along with clearance heights and height types.
dataset.title: Overhead Bridges

dataset.description: Evanston Police Department divides the City of Evanston into eight patrol beats.
dataset.title: Police patrol beats

dataset.description: Fences within the City of Evanston.
dataset.title: Fences

dataset.description: The approximately 22.5 miles of railroad tracks in the City of Evanston are traveled by both CTA to Metra trains.
dataset.title: Railroad tracks

dataset.description: This layer shows the edges of paved sidewalks throughout the City of Evanston.
dataset.title: Sidewalks

dataset.description: Trash is picked up in the City of Evanston on a four day schedule.
dataset.title: Refuse collection days

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has just under 120 intersections controlled by traffic signals.
dataset.title: Traffic signal intersections

dataset.description: This layer shows a parking lots within the City of Evanston as captured from aerial photos.
dataset.title: Parking lots

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has just over 120 cul-de-sacs.
dataset.title: Cul-de-sacs

dataset.description: Speed humps are a traffic calming device employed by the City of Evanston along with traffic circles.
dataset.title: Speed humps

dataset.description: A Transit Oriented Development (TOD) area is a development pattern created around a transit station that is characterized by higher density, mixed uses, pedestrian environment, reduced parking, and a direct and convenient access to the transit station. The initial boundaries and zones of each TOD area are described in Appendix A to Ordinance 60-O-15.
dataset.title: TOD area parcels

dataset.description: The Zoning Code is located in Title 6 of the Municipal City Code. The Zoning Code promotes the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, general welfare, objectives and policies of the comprehensive general plan. As adopted and amended by the Evanston City Council, the Zoning Code establishes and regulates buildings and building setbacks along streets, alleys, property lines, use of lot areas, parking and loading, and the areas of open space between and among surrounding buildings.
dataset.title: Zoning overlay districts

dataset.description: This layer shows bodies of water in and around the City of Evanston. The chief among these is Lake Michigan to the east with 4.25 miles of shoreline. The data also includes 3 miles of the North Shore Channel, the 14.2 acre Northwestern Lagoon, and various other ponds.
dataset.title: Water bodies

dataset.description: The Zoning Code is located in Title 6 of the Municipal City Code. The Zoning Code promotes the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, general welfare, objectives and policies of the comprehensive general plan. As adopted and amended by the Evanston City Council, the Zoning Code establishes and regulates buildings and building setbacks along streets, alleys, property lines, use of lot areas, parking and loading, and the areas of open space between and among surrounding buildings.
dataset.title: Zoning Districts

dataset.description: The City of Evanston is approximately 7.8 square miles and bounded by Lake Michigan to the east, Chicago to the south, Skokie to the west, and Wilmette to the north.
dataset.title: The City of Evanston

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has just under 100 crosswalks ranging from pedestrian crossings to school crossing guard locations to senior crossings.
dataset.title: Crosswalks

dataset.description: The City of Evanston uses one-way streets to help the flow of traffic and make driving safer along with other tools like speed humps and traffic circles.
dataset.title: One-way streets

dataset.description:
The City of Evanston maintains 76 of its own parks spread over 
273 acres. This parks layer also includes 10 Ridgeville Park District 
parks, 2 Lighthouse Park District Parks, 1 Cook County Forest Preserve 
(Perkins Woods) and the portion of the Canal Shores Golf Course within 
the City of Evanston as well as 2 parks just 
over the city's western boundary which we jointly operate with the 
Village of Skokie.
      .
dataset.title: Parks

dataset.description: The City of Evanston is divided into nine wards. Each ward is then sub-divided into precincts. One alderman is elected to represent each ward.
dataset.title: Precincts

dataset.description:
The City of Evanston has designated certain areas of the city as Tax Increment Financing, or TIF, districts. TIF Districts are established in compliance with State of Illinois 
statutes. The mechanism is designed to assist financially desirable 
developments that but for the financial assistance would not be able to 
achieve.
dataset.title: Tax Increment Financing (TIF) districts

dataset.description: The City of Evanston designates some streets around schools as temporary one-ways at certain times to facilitate safer pick-ups and drop-offs.
dataset.title: Temporary school one-way streets

dataset.description:
As a part of the Field Operations Division, the Problem Solving Team's 
(PST) uniformed officers provide motorized patrol along with highly 
visible foot and bike patrol in neighborhoods. PST officers serve as a 
community policing mechanism by making personal contacts with area 
residents and merchants as well as providing a broad spectrum of 
proactive and preventive community services (attending neighborhood 
meetings/block club development, security surveys, etc.).
dataset.title: Problem Solving Team (PST) beats

dataset.description:
The City of Evanston has inventoried and maintains over 34,000 trees located on City property and in the parkways.

The data provided on trees located within the City of Evanston was collected in 2014.  Maintenance and tree preservation efforts are an ongoing part of the City operations, thus the data contained herein does not represent current figures.
dataset.title: Trees

dataset.description: The National Register of Historic Places is part of the National Park Service. Four National Register historic districts have been designated in the City of Evanston. They consist of the Northeast, Ridge, Lakeshore and Oakton historic districts.
dataset.title: Federal historic districts

dataset.description: The City of Evanston maintains 6 beaches along the beautiful shore of Lake Michigan, one of which is dedicated for use by dogs.
dataset.title: Beaches

dataset.description:
A Special Service Area (SSA) is defined by Illinois State Statute as a 
contiguous area within a municipality or county in which special 
services are provided in addition to those services provided generally 
throughout the municipality or county. Special services include things 
like landscaping, advertising, public art, and extra garbage 
collections. The special services are paid from revenues collected from 
taxes levied or imposed upon property within that area.
dataset.title: Special Service Areas (SSAs)

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has just over 1 square mile of street and alleys covering its surface which comes to about 13.5% of total land area. This layer shows the areas covered by streets and alleys, both paved and unpaved.
dataset.title: Streets and alleys

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has approximately 147 miles of street centerlines within its borders. These centerlines are coded with address ranges for use in geocoding and also includes honorary street names, speed limits, and ownership data. McCormick Blvd, while in Skokie, is included with this data as it serves as an important N-S thoroughfare.
dataset.title: Street centerlines

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has just over 17,000 primary site addresses. This data does not include sub-units such as apartments, condominiums, or suites.
dataset.title: Addresses

dataset.description: There are approximately 27,000 different structures in the City of Evanston ranging from buildings to garages to decks & patios to swimming pools. This layer consists of the footprints of the different sections of these structures. Large buildings with multiple levels are broken down into sections by number of stories.
dataset.title: Buildings

dataset.description: The City of Evanston has approximately 45 miles of protected bike lanes, bike lanes, bike routes and off-street paths.
dataset.title: Bicycle routes, lanes, and paths
